item.summary: LongHashedRelation test fails on Big Endian platform

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
davies as you are the author of this code can you comment on my findings?

So the issue here is that the keyGenerator returns an UnsafeRow containing Int values but the code below from LongHashedRelation.apply retrieves the key from this as a Long. The bytes in the row are

on Little Endian: 01 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
on Big Endian: 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 00

By chance getInt and getLong will both return "1" on Little Endian because the following 4 bytes happen to be 0, whereas on Big Endian getInt returns "1" but get Long will return "268435456"

    val keyGenerator = UnsafeProjection.create(key)

    // Create a mapping of key -> rows
    var numFields = 0
    while (input.hasNext) {
      val unsafeRow = input.next().asInstanceOf[UnsafeRow]
      numFields = unsafeRow.numFields()
      val rowKey = keyGenerator(unsafeRow)
      if (!rowKey.isNullAt(0)) {
        val key = rowKey.getLong(0) // <<<---- Values in rowKey are Ints not Longs
        map.append(key, unsafeRow)
      }
    }

Is this just a testcase issue where in HashedRelationSuite

    val key = Seq(BoundReference(0, IntegerType, false))

should be

    val key = Seq(BoundReference(0, LongType, false))

Ans: No, still fails with that change.

I'm convinced the test is invalid. The creation of LongHashedRelation is guarded by

   if (key.length == 1 && key.head.dataType == LongType) {
      LongHashedRelation(input, key, sizeEstimate, mm)
    }

In this failing test the key dataType is IntegerType

I'll submit a PR to fix the tests
